item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Barrister and Solicitor

390 Bay Street, Suite 1402, Toronto, Ontario, Canada M5H 2Y2

Direct

416 252 5555

Email

jos@johnosullivanlaw.com

Head Clerk

Daniela Ferreira daniela@johnosullivanlaw.com 416 252 5555 Contacting Mr O'Sullivan by email does not mean he is acting as lawyer for the person who sent the email. Mr O'Sullivan must first agree to act. That agreement will be confirmed in a retainer letter. No information should be provided to Mr O'Sullivan in an email without his prior agreement, unless the sender is an existing client, and such information will not be considered confidential.

item.title: Biography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
John O'Sullivan practises civil litigation with an emphasis on court advocacy in contentious trusts and estates, business and real estate matters. O'Sullivan practised at a downtown Toronto law firm until 2012 when he withdrew from the partnership to offer clients 25 years of experience in court advocacy at competitive rates, by combining lower overhead with a counsel fee structure that de-emphasizes traditional hourly billings and rewards results and speed of resolution. O'Sullivan has appeared before all levels of court including the Supreme Court of Canada. Trusts and Estates Litigation: will challenges, testamentary capacity, trustee applications for directions, estate accounts disputes, claims by and against estates, dependent's relief, guardianship. O'Sullivan is recognized in Best Lawyers in the specialty of Trusts and Estates for 2010, 2011, 2012. He is also recognized as a Registered Contentious Trust and Probate Specialist and member of A.C.T.A.P.S. Business Litigation: rectification applications; contract disputes, oppression remedies, shareholder disputes. Real Estate Litigation: rights of first refusal, options, easements, contractual rights, adverse possession; A native of London U.K., John maintains his many legal, business, social and family connections there and travels there regularly. He lives in mid-town Toronto with his wife and two children. He is a regular contributor to the Canadian law blog http://www.slaw.ca/
Practice Areas
Civil Litigation
Called to the Bar
Ontario (1988)
Education
University of Ottawa LL.B. 1986 University of Western Ontario M.A. 1979 University of Exeter B.A. (Hons) 1978

Speaking Engagements

Panellist, IBC’s 3rd Annual Trust Litigation Symposium  London, England, 8 November 2011. Panellist, IBC Legal Conferences, 9th Annual International Trusts Congress 2010, London, England, December 1-2, 2010. Speaker, "What Privilege Does a Trustee Enjoy?", The Law Society of Upper Canada, 13th Annual Estates and Trustes Summit, Toronto, November 17-18, 2010. Speaker, "The Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act", Toronto Estate Planning Council, Toronto, February 5, 2002. Speaker, "Corruption, Money Laundering and the Use (and Abuse) of Offshore Financial Institutions - Update on the New Anti-Money Laundering Legislation in Canada", Inter-American Bar Association, Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, June 2001. Speaker, "Recent Anti-money Laundering and Anti-corruption Initiatives in Canada", Law Forum: 2000 and Beyond, Nassau, Bahamas, February 2000. Speaker, "Some private sector perspectives regarding anti-corruption initiatives in Canada and the prospects for Canadian signature and ratification of the OAS Inter-American Convention Against Corruption", Inter-American Bar Association, Mexico City, June 1999. Speaker, "The Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act - The offence of bribery and some anticipated practical problems for Canadian business abroad", Canadian Bar Association (Ontario), Toronto, March 1999.

Awards & Recognition

Recognized as a Registered Contentious Trust and Probate Specialist. Recognized in the 2010 and 2011 editions of Best Lawyers in the specialty of Trusts and Estates. Award winning teacher of trial advocacy, Faculty of Law of Queen's University.

Professional Activities

Trusts & Estates, Section Executive, Ontario Bar Association (2010-2013) Civil Litigation, Section Executive, Ontario Bar Association (2010-2013) Chair, "Unbundling Working Group of the Professional Regulation Committee" Regarding Limited-Scope Legal Services/Representation, Ontario Bar Associaton (submission made to the Law Society of Upper Canada), Toronto, January 20, 2010. Advocacy, Faculty of Law of Queen's University (1999, 2000 and 2001) Civil Procedure , Osgoode Hall Law School (1994 and 1995). John O'Sullivan was a member of the Canadian Bar Association Working Group on Combating Corruption in International Business, and a member of the Executive of the International Law Section of the Ontario Bar Association. He has authored and delivered several papers on Canada's anti money laundering and anti bribery legislation at conferences in Canada and abroad. In February 2003, he chaired and participated in several panels appearing before the OECD review team of Canada's performance of its obligations under the Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions.

Affiliations

Transparency International Canada Ontario Bar Association Canadian Bar Association Commonwealth Lawyers Association

Other

1985 - an intern in the office of Judge Alex Kozinski then Chief Judge of the United States Claims Court in Washington D.C., now of the U.S. Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit. Special Assistant to the Hon. Serge Joyal, Secretary of State in the 1980-1984 government of the Hon. Pierre Trudeau.

item.title: Practice Areas
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
John O’Sullivan practises civil litigation with an emphasis on highly specialized court advocacy in contentious trusts and estates, business and real estate matters. In January 2013 O’Sullivan was selected by his peers for inclusion in the seventh edition of Best Lawyers in Canada. O'Sullivan's model of referral advocacy strives to offer first class, specialized advocacy to referring lawyer and client. O’Sullivan is consistently recognized in Best Lawyers in the specialty of Trusts and Estates (2010, 2011, 2012, 2013). He is also recognized as a Registered Contentious Trust and Probate Specialist and member of A.C.T.A.P.S. Trusts and Estates Litigation: will challenges, testamentary capacity, trustee applications for directions, estate accounts disputes, claims by and against estates, dependent’s relief, guardianship. Business Litigation: rectification applications; contract disputes, oppression remedies, shareholder disputes. Real Estate Litigation: rights of first refusal, options, easements, contractual rights, adverse possession.

Referral Advocacy - "Keep the Client, Lose the Headache"

item.title: Referral Advocacy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Referral Advocacy Service for Lawyers - "Keep the Client, Lose the Headache"

Referral advocacy is a model by which court advocacy is undertaken by a specialist bar (barristers) to whom other lawyers refer as needed. Advocacy specialists focus their practices on preparing and presenting a case to a judge or arbitrator. They don't need the trappings of a law firm to do their work.  They can therefore offer more court experience, and lower overhead.  This is a deadly combination which can give a party a significant leg up. O'Sullivan offers specialist advocacy services to lawyers at any stage in the litigation process including pleadings, examinations for discovery, opinions on merits, prior to mediation, after unsuccessful mediation, and at all hearings: motions for final orders, injunctions, arbitrations, trials and appeals. The referral advocacy model is used in much of the Commonwealth and in England and Wales, where it continues to thrive despite legislation in 1990 that removed the exclusive rights of the Bar to appear in the Superior Courts.

Strategic Advantages

"An understanding of the trial process is the unique skill of the trial lawyer and that skill is derived from the courtroom." — Advocates Society Task Force on Advocacy, June 2004
More predictable cost
Referred advocates can usually offer a fixed price for  a hearing, instead of an hourly rate, because they can normally judge the amount of their time that will be needed.  Predictable cost makes it possible to weigh risks more effectively and to budget.
Mediation Advantage
A party to a mediation who has a committed fee amount for the trial has greater bargaining strength than an opponent whose trial costs are uncertain.
Expertise Advantage
A party who is represented at a hearing by a specialist advocate has an advantage over an opponent whose lawyer has little advocacy experience.
Incentive
A referred advocate feels only as good as their last case. Their business is repeat referrals. They devote their all to the case in hand.

Benefits for the referring lawyer

"In many ways a trial, like skydiving, is not inherently difficult; however both can be terribly unforgiving of the slightest inattention." — Courting Justice, David Boies
Lawyers who refer to specialist advocates when needed lose the headaches of trial work, the havoc it wreaks on a practice, and the responsibility for an unfavourable outcome. Yet they can secure for their client the added advantage of specialist advocacy services at a predictable cost. They transfer the risk of cost overruns to the advocate and they earn the client's gratitude when the outcome is favourable. There is no disruption to the relationship between the referring lawyer and client. The client always remains that of the referring lawyer, who takes the file back at the conclusion. The referring lawyer remains as involved in the case as they and the client wish, working closely with the advocacy specialist to make full use of all the matter history and knowledge the referring lawyer has acquired. The ongoing litigation services other than advocacy remain within the broader retainer of the referring lawyer. One UK solicitor explains the benefit to the referring lawyer this way: "When solicitors in the UK refer their clients to barristers for specialist advocacy work, solicitors often find they have the time to take on new clients and spend more quality time with them, because the headache of attending court or arbitrations has been taken off their hands. This leads to increased revenue, benefiting the solicitor personally and the law firm."

Benefits for the client

Frequently a party to a lawsuit justifiably feels confident in his or her case and wants their "day in court". The pressure to mediate or settle through other alternative dispute mechanisms is strong because the cost of proceeding to trial and the outcome often cannot be predicted within acceptable limits of risk. The greater predictability of cost combined with the use of a lawyer who specializes in advocacy can make proceeding to trial a realistic option for parties involved in litigation. A UK solicitor describes a two-fold benefit for clients in the referred advocacy model as follows: "First, the client gets a more personal and attentive service from their solicitor, making them feel comfortable and confident in the legal services that are being provided. Second, the client has the knowledge that their case is being fought on two fronts by two dedicated specialists, each one having their own individual skill set."

item.title: Junior Lawyers, Paralegals and Clerks

item.content:encoded: We are always interested in talking to energetic lawyers, paralegals and clerks who are interested in providing top quality civil litigation services focused on speed of resolution at predictable, proportional cost.   Please call to discuss.

item.title: Mission Statement
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: We are committed to offering premium quality civil litigation services focused on speed of resolution and proportional cost.

item.title: Seminars and Events
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ontario Bar Association’s Institute 2013 Trusts and Estates Law

Best Practices, Practical Tips, and Risk Management Strategies for Estate Planning.

Date: Thursday 7th February 2013 / 1:30pm  - 4:50pm. Location: Westin Harbour Castle Conference Centre | 2 Harbour Square | Toronto, ON | M5J 1A6. Program Chairs: John O’Sullivan (John O’Sullivan Law) and Ed Upenieks (Lawrence Lawrence Stevenson LLP) Learn from leading practitioners and a Superior Court Judge the best practices, practical tips and risk management strategies for estate planning, estate administration, and estate litigation. John O'Sullivan will be specifically moderating the Emerging Trends: New Causes of Action talk at 4:05pm which will include: Developing case law from the UK and Offshore - including trustee and investment advisor/asset manager liability for investment losses; the current state of exculpation clauses and the rise of Singapore. What’s coming to Ontario?
  • Proprietary Estoppel Claims
  • Tort of Intentional Interference
  • Disclosure of Documents in a Fiduciary Context
